intro: Coreopsis glaucodes, commonly known as the blue mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the eastern and central United States. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 2 to 4 feet, featuring upright stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, daisy-like flowers with white petals and a yellow center, blooming from late summer into early fall. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soils, making it a popular choice for gardens and natural landscapes. Its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies adds ecological value to its environment.
